ygData.subject: General Game Playing
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello list, I thought you all might be interested. Erkin Bahceci, Igor Karpov and myself are planning on entering a NEAT-based system in the AAAI General Game

Hello list,

I thought you all might be interested. Erkin Bahceci, Igor Karpov and  
myself are planning on entering a NEAT-based system in the AAAI  
General Game Playing Competition:

http://games.stanford.edu

Its a pretty neat competition. Basically your agent is given a game  
described in a generic specification language and within some amount  
of time it has to learn to play the game (hopefully well enough to  
beat your opponent). The game language is surprisingly general; games  
can have any number of players (e.g. tower-of-hanoi has 1 whereas  
chinese checkers has 6) and they can be turn-based or simultaneous.  
The only restriction at the moment is that the games have to be  
perfect-knowledge, which precludes things like battleship.

There are a few really nice points about GGP. First, it forces us to  
pay more attention to our algorithm and less to fine-tuning of  
parameters and input representations. NE is much more difficult when  
you don't know what your inputs are going to be! Second, it should be  
a good indicator of where NE actually ranks in terms of being a  
general architecture for AI (the competition seems very fair and  
consists of three weeks of qualification rounds before the final at  
AAAI). Third, the parser we're writing for the game language is  
completely reusable, and gives us instant access to a pretty large  
number of games for testing (finally we can run validations on simple  
games that are more interesting than tic-tac-toe). Some of the more  
well known games already included in ggp are Connect-Four, Othello,  
Tetris, Capture Go, Chinese Checkers, Guess the number, tower of  
Hanoi, nine-mens-morris, 10 Queens, rock-paper-scissors (for deciding  
who goes first, of course), and tic-tac-toe.

We've just gotten to the point where we can do real experiments with  
our system, so stay tuned for actual results.

Has anyone else on the list thought about entering?

-- Joe
